members.member: Sets the GIF frame disposal code for the last added frame and any subsequent frames. Default is 0 if no transparent color has been set, otherwise 2. @param code int disposal code.

Sets the transparent color for the last added frame and any subsequent frames. Since all colors are subject to modification in the quantization process, the color in the final palette for each frame closest to the given color becomes the transparent color for that frame. May be set to null to indicate no transparent color.
@param c Color to be treated as transparent on display.

Adds next GIF frame. The frame is not written immediately, but is actually deferred until the next frame is received so that timing data can be inserted. Invoking finish() flushes all frames. If setSize was not invoked, the size of the first image is used for all subsequent frames.
@param im BufferedImage containing frame to write. @return true if successful.
Flushes any pending data and closes output file. If writing to an OutputStream, the stream is not closed.

Sets quality of color quantization (conversion of images to the maximum 256 colors allowed by the GIF specification). Lower values (minimum = 1) produce better colors, but slow processing significantly. 10 is the default, and produces good color mapping at reasonable speeds. Values greater than 20 do not yield significant improvements in speed.
@param quality int greater than 0. @return
Analyzes image colors and creates color map.
Returns index of palette color closest to c

Reads Netscape extenstion to obtain iteration count

Encodes multiple images as an animated gif to a stream.
ALWAYS wire this up in a "using" block
Disposing the encoder will complete the file.

member.summary:
Encodes multiple images as an animated gif to a stream.
ALWAYS ALWAYS ALWAYS wire this in a using block
Disposing the encoder will complete the file.
Uses default .net GIF encoding and adds animation headers.

Sets the height for this gif or null to use the first frame's height.

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.Program.Main
member.summary: The main entry point for the application.

member.name: T:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook
member.summary: This class allows you to tap keyboard and mouse and / or to detect their activity even when an application runes in background or does not have any user interface at all. This class raises common .NET events with KeyEventArgs and MouseEventArgs so you can easily retrive any information you need.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WH_MOUSE_LL
member.summary: Windows NT/2000/XP: Installs a hook procedure that monitors low-level mouse input events.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WH_KEYBOARD_LL
member.summary: Windows NT/2000/XP: Installs a hook procedure that monitors low-level keyboard input events.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WH_MOUSE
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that monitors mouse messages. For more information, see the MouseProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WH_KEYBOARD
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that monitors keystroke messages. For more information, see the KeyboardProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_MOUSEMOVE
member.summary: The WM_MOUSEMOVE message is posted to a window when the cursor moves.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_LBUTTONDOWN
member.summary: The WM_LBUTTONDOWN message is posted when the user presses the left mouse button

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_RBUTTONDOWN
member.summary: The WM_RBUTTONDOWN message is posted when the user presses the right mouse button

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_MBUTTONDOWN
member.summary: The WM_MBUTTONDOWN message is posted when the user presses the middle mouse button

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_LBUTTONUP
member.summary: The WM_LBUTTONUP message is posted when the user releases the left mouse button

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_RBUTTONUP
member.summary: The WM_RBUTTONUP message is posted when the user releases the right mouse button

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_MBUTTONUP
member.summary: The WM_MBUTTONUP message is posted when the user releases the middle mouse button

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_LBUTTONDBLCLK
member.summary: The WM_LBUTTONDBLCLK message is posted when the user double-clicks the left mouse button

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_RBUTTONDBLCLK
member.summary: The WM_RBUTTONDBLCLK message is posted when the user double-clicks the right mouse button

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_MBUTTONDBLCLK
member.summary: The WM_RBUTTONDOWN message is posted when the user presses the right mouse button

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_MOUSEWHEEL
member.summary: The WM_MOUSEWHEEL message is posted when the user presses the mouse wheel.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_KEYDOWN
member.summary: The WM_KEYDOWN message is posted to the window with the keyboard focus when a nonsystem key is pressed. A nonsystem key is a key that is pressed when the ALT key is not pressed.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_KEYUP
member.summary: The WM_KEYUP message is posted to the window with the keyboard focus when a nonsystem key is released. A nonsystem key is a key that is pressed when the ALT key is not pressed, or a keyboard key that is pressed when a window has the keyboard focus.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_SYSKEYDOWN
member.summary: The WM_SYSKEYDOWN message is posted to the window with the keyboard focus when the user presses the F10 key (which activates the menu bar) or holds down the ALT key and then presses another key. It also occurs when no window currently has the keyboard focus; in this case, the WM_SYSKEYDOWN message is sent to the active window. The window that receives the message can distinguish between these two contexts by checking the context code in the lParam parameter.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.WM_SYSKEYUP
member.summary: The WM_SYSKEYUP message is posted to the window with the keyboard focus when the user releases a key that was pressed while the ALT key was held down. It also occurs when no window currently has the keyboard focus; in this case, the WM_SYSKEYUP message is sent to the active window. The window that receives the message can distinguish between these two contexts by checking the context code in the lParam parameter.

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.SetWindowsHookEx(System.Int32,ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.HookProc,System.IntPtr,System.Int32)
member.summary: The SetWindowsHookEx function installs an application-defined hook procedure into a hook chain. You would install a hook procedure to monitor the system for certain types of events. These events are associated either with a specific thread or with all threads in the same desktop as the calling thread.
member.param: [in] Specifies the type of hook procedure to be installed. This parameter can be one of the following values.

[in] Pointer to the hook procedure. If the dwThreadId parameter is zero or specifies the identifier of a thread created by a different process, the lpfn parameter must point to a hook procedure in a dynamic-link library (DLL). Otherwise, lpfn can point to a hook procedure in the code associated with the current process.

[in] Handle to the DLL containing the hook procedure pointed to by the lpfn parameter. The hMod parameter must be set to NULL if the dwThreadId parameter specifies a thread created by the current process and if the hook procedure is within the code associated with the current process.

[in] Specifies the identifier of the thread with which the hook procedure is to be associated. If this parameter is zero, the hook procedure is associated with all existing threads running in the same desktop as the calling thread.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the handle to the hook procedure. If the function fails, the return value is NULL. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.UnhookWindowsHookEx(System.Int32)
member.summary: The UnhookWindowsHookEx function removes a hook procedure installed in a hook chain by the SetWindowsHookEx function.
member.param: [in] Handle to the hook to be removed. This parameter is a hook handle obtained by a previous call to SetWindowsHookEx.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.CallNextHookEx(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The CallNextHookEx function passes the hook information to the next hook procedure in the current hook chain. A hook procedure can call this function either before or after processing the hook information.
member.param: Ignored.
[in] Specifies the hook code passed to the current hook procedure. The next hook procedure uses this code to determine how to process the hook information.
[in] Specifies the wParam value passed to the current hook procedure. The meaning of this parameter depends on the type of hook associated with the current hook chain.
[in] Specifies the lParam value passed to the current hook procedure. The meaning of this parameter depends on the type of hook associated with the current hook chain.
member.returns: This value is returned by the next hook procedure in the chain. The current hook procedure must also return this value. The meaning of the return value depends on the hook type. For more information, see the descriptions of the individual hook procedures.

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.ToAscii(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: The ToAscii function translates the specified virtual-key code and keyboard state to the corresponding character or characters. The function translates the code using the input language and physical keyboard layout identified by the keyboard layout handle.
member.param: [in] Specifies the virtual-key code to be translated.
[in] Specifies the hardware scan code of the key to be translated. The high-order bit of this value is set if the key is up (not pressed).

[in] Pointer to a 256-byte array that contains the current keyboard state. Each element (byte) in the array contains the state of one key. If the high-order bit of a byte is set, the key is down (pressed). The low bit, if set, indicates that the key is toggled on. In this function, only the toggle bit of the CAPS LOCK key is relevant. The toggle state of the NUM LOCK and SCROLL LOCK keys is ignored.
[out] Pointer to the buffer that receives the translated character or characters.
[in] Specifies whether a menu is active. This parameter must be 1 if a menu is active, or 0 otherwise.
member.returns: If the specified key is a dead key, the return value is negative. Otherwise, it is one of the following values. Value Meaning 0 The specified virtual key has no translation for the current state of the keyboard. 1 One character was copied to the buffer. 2 Two characters were copied to the buffer. This usually happens when a dead-key character (accent or diacritic) stored in the keyboard layout cannot be composed with the specified virtual key to form a single character.

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.GetKeyboardState(System.Byte[])
member.summary: The GetKeyboardState function copies the status of the 256 virtual keys to the specified buffer.
member.param: [in] Pointer to a 256-byte array that contains keyboard key states.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.#ctor
member.summary: Creates an instance of UserActivityHook object and sets mouse and keyboard hooks.

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.#ctor(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates an instance of UserActivityHook object and installs both or one of mouse and/or keyboard hooks and starts rasing events
member.param: true if mouse events must be monitored
true if keyboard events must be monitored
member.remarks: To create an instance without installing hooks call new UserActivityHook(false, false)

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.Finalize
member.summary: Destruction.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.hMouseHook
member.summary: Stores the handle to the mouse hook procedure.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.hKeyboardHook
member.summary: Stores the handle to the keyboard hook procedure.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseHookProcedure
member.summary: Declare MouseHookProcedure as HookProc type.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.KeyboardHookProcedure
member.summary: Declare KeyboardHookProcedure as HookProc type.

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.Start
member.summary: Installs both mouse and keyboard hooks and starts rasing events

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.Start(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Installs both or one of mouse and/or keyboard hooks and starts rasing events
member.param: true if mouse events must be monitored
true if keyboard events must be monitored

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.Stop
member.summary: Stops monitoring both mouse and keyboard events and rasing events.

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.Stop(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Stops monitoring both or one of mouse and/or keyboard events and rasing events.
member.param: true if mouse hook must be uninstalled
true if keyboard hook must be uninstalled
true if exceptions which occured during uninstalling must be thrown

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseHookProc(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: A callback function which will be called every time a mouse activity detected.
member.param: [in] Specifies whether the hook procedure must process the message. If nCode is HC_ACTION, the hook procedure must process the message. If nCode is less than zero, the hook procedure must pass the message to the CallNextHookEx function without further processing and must return the value returned by CallNextHookEx.
[in] Specifies whether the message was sent by the current thread. If the message was sent by the current thread, it is nonzero; otherwise, it is zero.
[in] Pointer to a CWPSTRUCT structure that contains details about the message.
member.returns: If nCode is less than zero, the hook procedure must return the value returned by CallNextHookEx. If nCode is greater than or equal to zero, it is highly recommended that you call CallNextHookEx and return the value it returns; otherwise, other applications that have installed WH_CALLWNDPROC hooks will not receive hook notifications and may behave incorrectly as a result. If the hook procedure does not call CallNextHookEx, the return value should be zero.

member.name: M:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.KeyboardHookProc(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: A callback function which will be called every time a keyboard activity detected.
member.param: [in] Specifies whether the hook procedure must process the message. If nCode is HC_ACTION, the hook procedure must process the message. If nCode is less than zero, the hook procedure must pass the message to the CallNextHookEx function without further processing and must return the value returned by CallNextHookEx.
[in] Specifies whether the message was sent by the current thread. If the message was sent by the current thread, it is nonzero; otherwise, it is zero.
[in] Pointer to a CWPSTRUCT structure that contains details about the message.
member.returns: If nCode is less than zero, the hook procedure must return the value returned by CallNextHookEx. If nCode is greater than or equal to zero, it is highly recommended that you call CallNextHookEx and return the value it returns; otherwise, other applications that have installed WH_CALLWNDPROC hooks will not receive hook notifications and may behave incorrectly as a result. If the hook procedure does not call CallNextHookEx, the return value should be zero.

member.name: E:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.OnMouseActivity
member.summary: Occurs when the user moves the mouse, presses any mouse button or scrolls the wheel

member.summary: Occurs when the user presses a key

member.name: E:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.KeyPress
member.summary: Occurs when the user presses and releases

member.name: E:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.KeyUp
member.summary: Occurs when the user releases a key

member.name: T:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.POINT
member.summary: The POINT structure defines the x- and y- coordinates of a point.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.POINT.x
member.summary: Specifies the x-coordinate of the point.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.POINT.y
member.summary: Specifies the y-coordinate of the point.

member.name: T:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseHookStruct
member.summary: The MOUSEHOOKSTRUCT structure contains information about a mouse event passed to a WH_MOUSE hook procedure, MouseProc.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseHookStruct.pt
member.summary: Specifies a POINT structure that contains the x- and y-coordinates of the cursor, in screen coordinates.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseHookStruct.hwnd
member.summary: Handle to the window that will receive the mouse message corresponding to the mouse event.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseHookStruct.wHitTestCode
member.summary: Specifies the hit-test value. For a list of hit-test values, see the description of the WM_NCHITTEST message.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseHookStruct.dwExtraInfo
member.summary: Specifies extra information associated with the message.

member.name: T:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseLLHookStruct
member.summary: The MSLLHOOKSTRUCT structure contains information about a low-level keyboard input event.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseLLHookStruct.pt
member.summary: Specifies a POINT structure that contains the x- and y-coordinates of the cursor, in screen coordinates.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseLLHookStruct.mouseData
member.summary: If the message is WM_MOUSEWHEEL, the high-order word of this member is the wheel delta. The low-order word is reserved. A positive value indicates that the wheel was rotated forward, away from the user; a negative value indicates that the wheel was rotated backward, toward the user. One wheel click is defined as WHEEL_DELTA, which is 120. If the message is WM_XBUTTONDOWN, WM_XBUTTONUP, WM_XBUTTONDBLCLK, WM_NCXBUTTONDOWN, WM_NCXBUTTONUP, or WM_NCXBUTTONDBLCLK, the high-order word specifies which X button was pressed or released, and the low-order word is reserved. This value can be one or more of the following values. Otherwise, mouseData is not used. XBUTTON1 The first X button was pressed or released. XBUTTON2 The second X button was pressed or released.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseLLHookStruct.flags
member.summary: Specifies the event-injected flag. An application can use the following value to test the mouse flags. Value Purpose LLMHF_INJECTED Test the event-injected flag. 0 Specifies whether the event was injected. The value is 1 if the event was injected; otherwise, it is 0. 1-15 Reserved.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseLLHookStruct.time
member.summary: Specifies the time stamp for this message.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.MouseLLHookStruct.dwExtraInfo
member.summary: Specifies extra information associated with the message.

member.name: T:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.KeyboardHookStruct
member.summary: The KBDLLHOOKSTRUCT structure contains information about a low-level keyboard input event.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.KeyboardHookStruct.vkCode
member.summary: Specifies a virtual-key code. The code must be a value in the range 1 to 254.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.KeyboardHookStruct.scanCode
member.summary: Specifies a hardware scan code for the key.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.KeyboardHookStruct.flags
member.summary: Specifies the extended-key flag, event-injected flag, context code, and transition-state flag.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.KeyboardHookStruct.time
member.summary: Specifies the time stamp for this message.

member.name: F:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.KeyboardHookStruct.dwExtraInfo
member.summary: Specifies extra information associated with the message.

member.name: T:ScreenToGif.UserActivityHook.HookProc
member.summary: The CallWndProc hook procedure is an application-defined or library-defined callback function used with the SetWindowsHookEx function. The HOOKPROC type defines a pointer to this callback function. CallWndProc is a placeholder for the application-defined or library-defined function name.
member.param: [in] Specifies whether the hook procedure must process the message. If nCode is HC_ACTION, the hook procedure must process the message. If nCode is less than zero, the hook procedure must pass the message to the CallNextHookEx function without further processing and must return the value returned by CallNextHookEx.
[in] Specifies whether the message was sent by the current thread. If the message was sent by the current thread, it is nonzero; otherwise, it is zero.
[in] Pointer to a CWPSTRUCT structure that contains details about the message.
member.returns: If nCode is less than zero, the hook procedure must return the value returned by CallNextHookEx. If nCode is greater than or equal to zero, it is highly recommended that you call CallNextHookEx and return the value it returns; otherwise, other applications that have installed WH_CALLWNDPROC hooks will not receive hook notifications and may behave incorrectly as a result. If the hook procedure does not call CallNextHookEx, the return value should be zero.
